I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  Government  of  Uzbekistan  requested  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to 
provide technical assistance (TA)1 for capacity development to strengthen (i) the monitoring 
capacity for projects financed by ADB, other international financial institutions, and foreign 
investors; and (ii) debt management capacity.  
 
2.  In August 2012, ADB fielded a fact-finding mission to discuss possible ADB assistance 
with the Ministry for Foreign Economic Relations, Investments, and Trade (MFERIT) and the 
Ministry of Finance (MOF). The government and the mission reached an understanding on the 
scope, impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, 
and terms of reference for the consultants. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 
1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Uzbekistan's economy has been growing strongly since 2004. Diversifying the economy 
through industrial development, especially through private sector mobilization, has become the 
country’s priority. To meet the needs for physical infrastructure development and nonphysical 
institutional strengthening, Uzbekistan is significantly increasing borrowing from ADB and other 
international financial institutions.  
 
4.  Since 1996 when ADB began lending to Uzbekistan, 44 public sector loans totaling $3.3 
billion have been approved.2 The current country portfolio contains 20 projects with 24 active 
loans for $2.21 billion that provide support to seven sectors. The transport sector accounts for 
the  largest  share  of  ADB  assistance  (40%),  followed  by  energy  (23%),  water  supply  and 
sanitation (13%), agriculture and natural resources (11%), multisector (9%), finance (3%), and 
education (1%). ADB has recently expanded its operation, and provided four public loans ($655 
million)  in  2010  and  six  public  loans  ($878  million)  in  2011.  Meanwhile,  the  World  Bank 
approved three loans totaling $291 million in 2011, which is the largest amount it has provided 
in a single year. The Japan International Cooperation Agency resumed its loan operation in 
2010 and has provided $250 million on average in each fiscal year since then. 
 
5.  To ensure timely delivery of results under the increased operations, greater efforts are 
required to improve project monitoring and portfolio management. Though the government has 
a high-level portfolio monitoring structure in place, performance is shown to be on track in only 
half of the ADB-funded projects in 2012. Further efforts are required to strengthen the project 
monitoring  and  portfolio  management  capacity.  The  Department  of  Monitoring  of 
Implementation on Foreign Investments and Projects (DMIFIP) of the MFERIT is responsible for 
monitoring, reviewing, and analyzing portfolio performance on a quarterly basis to identify key 
implementation issues.3 However, the current monitoring system requires manual collection of 
information  in  spreadsheets  from  executing  agencies.  The  DMIFIP  needs  to  develop  a 
monitoring database, since it is of great importance to ensure appropriate and efficient use of 
foreign funds in implementing the strategic objectives of the government’s development policy. 
Timely acquisition of data on project implementation progress and prompt addressing of issues 
are crucial to achieving better portfolio management.

2 As of 31 December 2012.

6.  To assist the government in improving its portfolio performance monitoring system, it is 
important  to  strengthen  the  DMIFIP’s  capacity  to  coordinate  with  executing  agencies  and 
develop  a  unified  monitoring  system.  This  system  will  enable  the  DMIFIP  and  executing 
agencies  to  (i)  establish  a  database  of  foreign-assisted  projects  to  monitor  and  improve 
performance, and (ii) identify causes of delays in project implementation in a timely manner, 
enable resolution of the issues, and bring the project back on schedule, and (iii) give priority to 
improving overall portfolio performance of foreign-assisted projects in a sustainable manner.    
   
7.  Given the country’s growing debt portfolio and shift to less-concessional funding, there is 
also  a  need  to  strengthen  Uzbekistan’s  public  debt  management.  The  government  has 
introduced a number of measures to strengthen the capacity of the MOF by building a strategic 
and operational framework for debt management. The role of the Public External Debt Division 
(PEDD) of the MOF in accounting, auditing, and fund flow management has expanded, and its 
accountability as a service provider to line ministries is becoming more clearly defined. Effective 
management of data on domestic and external public debt is crucial. This will necessitate the 
compilation and processing of all debt-related data to enable reliable and complete internal and 
external  reporting  on  debt  and  related  issues.  However,  information  is  currently  manually 
recorded and maintained, which is not suitable for real-time debt management and analysis.  
 
8.  There is therefore a need for appropriate information technology systems to support 
effective  debt  management.  Strengthening  the  capacity  of  the  PEDD  and  adopting  an 
internationally recognized and used debt management system, such as the Debt Management 
and Financial Analysis System (DMFAS),4 will enable the MOF to develop a debt database 
containing detailed and aggregated data on loan contracts, bonds and grants, real operations 
(disbursements and debt service), as well as future operations. As the system can process large 
quantities of data, more time and energy can be deployed on analytical and management tasks.  
 
9.  The TA will address the need to improve the project monitoring management capacity, 
and improve the advanced debt management system to support the country’s macroeconomic 
objectives. The TA is aligned with ADB's country partnership strategy, 2012–20165 and is 
included in the country operations business plan, 2012–2014 for Uzbekistan,6 which highlights 
the need for capacity development in the overall management of the development process. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The impact of the proposed TA will be improved aid management in Uzbekistan. The 
focus will be on the portfolio of foreign-assisted projects and debt management recording. The 
outcome will be strengthened capacity for project and debt management within the government.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The TA will have the following components: (i) an established project management 
information system (PMIS) for ADB-funded projects and other foreign-assisted projects, and 
                                                
4  The DMFAS is a software package that can be used for recording, monitoring, reporting, and analysis. Usually 
installed in the finance ministry and/or central bank, it supports both external and domestic public debt (loans and 
securities), whether this be short, medium, or long term. It also provides coverage for private debt, grants, and 
onlent loans. The DMFAS program is a world leader in provision of technical cooperation and advisory services in 
the area of debt management.

3 
 (ii) updated debt management recording of the MOF through use of the DMFAS.  
 
12.  Component 1 of the TA will support the following key activities: (i) review and select the 
proposed computerized PMIS based on inputs from the technical working team (para. 16) and 
reports available in the MFERIT, (ii) procure hardware and software for the PMIS, (iii) establish 
a project database, (iv) establish an online monitoring system for line ministries’ evaluation of 
foreign-assisted project performance, and (v) train relevant agencies in preparing data and 
running the system. A new monitoring framework will be established with development partners 
for effective portfolio management. 
 
13.  Component 2 will support the following key activities: (i) review the current workload of 
the MOF to transfer the existing debt management system to the DMFAS; (ii) procure software 
and hardware to employ the DMFAS; and (iii) migrate all data to the DMFAS and conduct 
workshops and training for local staff on the debt analysis functionality of the DMFAS. The 
MOF, through the new debt management system, will be able to provide debt information 
regularly and more frequently, and start to analyze debt portfolio in depth for debt sustainability. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, of which $900,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V). The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office and workshop spaces, and other in-
kind contributions. The government will also bear the cost of taxes and duties for imported 
equipment. The details of cost estimates are in Appendix 2. All disbursements under the TA will 
be  made  in  accordance  with  the  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as 
amended from time to time). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  The MFERIT will be the executing agency and will act as the overall coordinator of the 
TA, which will start in September 2013 and run for 12 months. The deputy minister of the 
MFERIT will be appointed as project director and oversee TA implementation. The MFERIT will 
establish  the  project  management  unit  (PMU)  in  its  head  office  to  manage  project 
implementation. The executing agency will (i) coordinate with ADB the schedule and process of 
procurement and recruitment of consultants, (ii) prepare periodic progress reports based on 
inputs from project coordinators, (iii) monitor and evaluate the TA activities, and (iv) develop a 
training  program together  with  the  software  provider. The  deputy  minister  of  the  MFERIT, 
assisted by the PMU, will lead coordination with the MOF to implement the TA. A working group 
with members representing the MOF will be established for component 2 coordination.  
 
16.  For component 1, the MFERIT will be the implementing agency and will assign one of its 
staff as project coordinator. The project coordinator will undertake the following: (i) financial 
management for component 1, (ii) preparation of periodic reports to be submitted to the PMU, 
and (iii) training on project monitoring and portfolio management for the MFERIT and project 
executing agency officials. The implementing agency will deploy the following counterpart staff 
to work with the PMU: (i) project coordinator for component 1, (ii) hardware specialist, (iii) 
application software administrator, (iv) policies development and implementation staff, and (v) 
training staff (two persons). All the staff will be permanently assigned to sustain the system and 
operate the database established under the TA. The role of the project coordinator will change 
after completion of the TA, when the coordinator will become the manager for the PMIS. The 
technical working team will be established with members from all relevant departments within 
the MFERIT and line ministries managing foreign-assisted projects. The technical working team

4       
will meet routinely, but at least once a month, to work on PMIS technical matters. The PMIS will 
be developed based on inputs from the technical working team, recommendations from the 
needs assessment, and other available reports in the MFERIT. The implementing agency, with 
assistance from the PMU consultants, will coordinate with ADB the procurement process of the 
software  and  hardware  for  the  PMIS,  conduct  training  and  workshops  as  part  of  the  TA 
implementation, and run the PMIS trial and dissemination. 
 
17.  A  lesson  learned from previous  TA  projects7 is  to  avoid  selecting  an implementing 
agency such as cabinet of ministers which only has a coordinating role. The MFERIT is an 
oversight ministry but has clear responsibility for overall portfolio performance of foreign-funded 
projects and can be further involved in procurement processes of those projects at various 
stages. The MFERIT is considered the most appropriate agency to implement the TA. 
 
18.  For component 2, the MOF will be the implementing agency and will assign one of its 
officials as the project coordinator. The project coordinator will be responsible for implementing 
component 2, including financial management, preparing periodic reports, and assuring the 
quality of information to be provided to the PMU. The PEDD will establish a technical working 
team, if needed, with members from all relevant agencies involved in debt management. The 
implementing agency, with assistance from the consultants, will be responsible for coordinating 
with  ADB  the  procurement  process  for  software  and  hardware  for  the  DMFAS.  The 
implementing agency, with assistance from the consultants and the software supplier, will be 
also responsible for conducting trainings and workshops as part of the TA implementation, and 
maintaining and running the DMFAS program to produce required outputs on debt information 
and analysis. The role of the project coordinator will change after completion of the TA, and the 
coordinator will become the manager for the DMFAS.  
 
19.  Each  implementing  agency  will  hold  separate  responsibilities  for  (i)  efficient  and 
comprehensive  financial  management for  each  component,  and  (ii)  high-quality  and  timely 
delivery of the necessary reporting for each component. The project coordinators, who are 
authorized persons from the implementing agency, will undertake these responsibilities. 
 
20.  ADB will engage one international consultant (2.5 person-months) as a team leader, and 
one national consultant (9.0 person-months) as a deputy team leader; they will both assist in the 
implementation of components 1 and 2. Consultants will be recruited on an individual basis in 
accordance with the ADB Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to 
time). Consultancy services will be delivered intermittently. 
 
21.  The international consultant, acting as the team leader, will assist in implementing the 
TA in close consultation and coordination with the executing agency. Responsibilities of the 
team leader include (i) preparing the implementation plan; (ii) preparing the inception, final, and 
other  reports  to  be  submitted  to  ADB;  (iii)  monitoring  overall  TA  implementation;  and  (iv) 
together  with  the  software  provider,  developing  a  training  program  on  project  portfolio 
management for MFERIT and executing and implementing agency officials; and (iv) providing 
guidance on the procurement process. The national consultant acting as the deputy team leader 
will assist the team leader with day-to-day TA activities and implementation of components 1 
and 2.  
 
22.  Procurement of hardware and software with related services will be made by ADB and 
carried out in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to

time).  All  software  and  equipment  will  be  handed  over  to  implementing  agencies  upon 
completion of the TA. The government assures that necessary operation and subscription costs 
will be borne by the government and the hardware and software will be maintained and updated 
at its own expense. 
 
23.  Component  1.  The  procurement  of  software,  hardware,  and  related  services 
(installation, testing, and training) for the MFERIT will be carried out by ADB in accordance with 
ADB’s Procurement Guidelines. The MFERIT will supervise test running of the hardware and 
software conducted by the suppliers. The implementing agency for component 1 will issue the 
certificate of acceptance after installation and running tests are satisfactorily completed.  
 
24.  Component 2. The DMFAS, the software, and related services (installation, testing, and 
training) for the MOF will be procured directly9 from the United Nations Conference on Trade 
and  Development  (UNCTAD)  for  the  following  reasons:  (i)  the  DMFAS  is  internationally 
recognized debt management software which meets the government’s technical requirements; 
(ii) the DMFAS is the only major debt management software which has been installed in former 
Soviet Union countries; (iii) the DMFAS has strong partnerships with all major international 
organizations in debt management (such as the International Monetary Fund and the World 
Bank), reflecting their initiatives to improve debt management; (iv) sensitivity of handling debt 
data in Uzbekistan requires that parties involved in the procurement and implementation of 
component 2 are neutral and confidential, and their number is kept to a minimum (UNCTAD 
meets this requirement); (v) preparation of a bidding document involving private consultants and 
disclosure of the debt-related information to bidders for the procurement may be considered 
undesirable because of the sensitivity of the data; (vi) UNCTAD is the only debt management 
software package supplier which is neither a private firm nor a foreign-government-related 
agency; (vii) the DMFAS is the only software currently available in a Russian version; (viii) the 
DMFAS can only be used with an agreement with UNCTAD; and (ix) UNCTAD is the sole 
supplier of the DMFAS. The TA will support the subscription costs of using the DMFAS for 3 
years. The implementing agency for component 2 will issue the certificate of acceptance after 
installation and running tests are satisfactorily completed. 
 
25.  The DMFAS is a package which includes training and other related services which are 
closely linked to the debt management software itself. Thus, it is not efficient to separate the 
capacity development component from the software procurement package. The  completion 
report for Capacity Building of the Development Aid and Debt Management’s Debt Management 
Unit10 recommends combining three interventions, where software procurement and subsequent 
trainings (direct contracting with the software supplier) were separately granted, into one TA 
project for reasons of cost effectiveness.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
 
26.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $900,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Uzbekistan for Improving Portfolio and Debt Management System, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  An international and a national consultant will be engaged to implement the technical 
assistance (TA) in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (March 2013, as 
amended time to time) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The consultants will be hired on 
an individual basis, and provide their advisory services mainly for overall coordination of the TA 
and implementation of component 1. Component 2 will be conducted substantially through 
procurement of the identified debt management system program package.  
 
A.  Project  Information  Management  Specialist  and  Team  Leader  (international, 2.5 
person-months, intermittent)  
 
2.  The team leader should have (i) strong experience in and knowledge of developing 
project monitoring information management systems; (ii) at least 10 years of experience in 
project management information systems (PMISs) and procurement of software and hardware, 
preferably in an international organization; and (iii) an advanced degree in a relevant field. 
Regional and country experience will be an advantage. The consultant’s responsibilities will 
include the following: 
 
1.  Overall Coordination of the Technical Assistance 
 
3.  As a team leader the consultant will assist the Ministry for Foreign Economic Relations, 
Investment and Trade (MFERIT), especially the deputy minister, with overall implementation of 
the TA. The team leader will be responsible for preparing the inception report covering the work 
plan for implementation of the TA, and midterm and final reports.    
 
4.  The team leader will guide the deputy team leader who will be responsible for everyday 
implementation of the TA. 
 
2.  Component 1 
 
5.  In close coordination with the MFERIT and technical working team composed of officials 
from related ministries, the team leader will be responsible for identifying appropriate new 
software and hardware, with technical specifications, for establishing the PMIS. This can be 
done by reviewing the needs assessment and other available reports on the development of the 
PMIS prepared by the MFERIT, and assess its suitability with the current and future project 
management system. 
 
6.  The team leader will develop the technical specifications of the software and hardware, 
prepare draft bidding documents, and, if required, assist ADB in evaluating bids and contract. 
The software and hardware will be procured by ADB. 
 
7.  The team leader has to ensure that the successful supplier of the software and hardware 
package  includes  a  comprehensive  training  program,  manuals,  adequate  resources  for 
collecting data, and transfer of data inputs and standard operating procedures for running the 
PMIS.    
 
8.  The team leader will work closely with the winner to ensure that training for the MFERIT 
and line ministries employing the PMIS is well planned and conducted, and to ensure that the 
PMIS is effectively operated and maintained.

Appendix 3       11 
 
 
3.  Component 2 
 
9.  In close coordination with the Ministry of Finance (MOF), the team leader will assist ADB 
with contract negotiation and contract management, if necessary. 
 
B.  Project Monitoring Specialist and Deputy Team Leader (national, 9 person-months, 
intermittent) 
 
10.  The deputy team leader will be responsible for everyday implementation of the TA. To 
effectively assist the MFERIT with overall implementation of the TA and its components 1 and 2, 
the deputy team leader will have an office in the MFERIT. 
 
11.  The consultant should have (i) a relevant background education and experience  in 
managing project implementation, especially in developing management information systems 
and procurement; (ii) more than 7 years of experience in project implementation, and preferably 
be familiar with managing ADB-assisted projects, especially involving procurement of software 
and hardware; and (iii) knowledge of government legal and institutional frameworks. 
 
12.  The deputy team leader will 
(i)  assist the MFERIT with everyday activities to implement this TA;  
(ii)  assist with day-to-day activities to implement components 1 and 2, in close 
coordination with the project coordinators; 
(iii)  provide inputs for preparing the inception, midterm, and final reports that will be 
prepared by the team leader; 
(iv)  be responsible for preparing the financial report on TA implementation, including 
liquidation of expenses; 
(v)  assist the MFERIT with holding meetings of the technical working team, and 
organizing workshops, trainings and seminars for implementation of the PMIS 
and other trainings under components 1 and 2, if required by the MOF; 
(vi)  work closely with the contractors to ensure that materials for training are 
available and complete; 
(vii)  facilitate communications between the software and hardware contractors or 
suppliers and all line ministries implementing foreign-assisted project to collect 
data needed for running PMIS; 
(viii)  assist the MFERIT and MOF to issue a certificate for acceptance of the PMIS 
and debt management system from the contractor or supplier; and 
(ix)  undertake other tasks related to implementation of the TA.
